abstract.text: CS-917 (MB06322) is a selective small compound inhibitor of fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase), which is expected to be a novel drug for the treatment of type 2 diabetes by inhibiting gluconeogenesis.
CS-917 is a bisamidate prodrug and activation of CS-917 requires a two-step enzyme catalyzed reaction.

The first-step enzyme, esterase, catalyzes the conversion of CS-917 into the intermediate form (R-134450) and the second-step enzyme, phosphoramidase, catalyzes the conversion of R-134450 into the active form (R-125338).
In this study, we biochemically purified the CS-917 esterase activity in monkey small intestine and liver.
We identified cathepsin A (CTSA) and elastase 3B (ELA3B) as CS-917 esterases in the small intestine by mass spectrometry, whereas we found CTSA and carboxylesterase 1 (CES1) in monkey liver.

We also purified R-134450 phosphoramidase activity in monkey liver and identified sphingomyelin phosphodiesterase, acid-like 3A (SMPADL3A), as an R-134450 phosphoramidase, which has not been reported to have any enzyme activity.
Recombinant human CTSA, ELA3B, and CES1 showed CS-917 esterase activity and recombinant human SMPDL3A showed R-134450 phosphoramidase activity, which confirmed the identification of those enzymes.

Identification of metabolic enzymes responsible for the activation process is the requisite first step to understanding the activation process, pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of CS-917 at the molecular level.

This is the first identification of a phosphoramidase other than histidine triad nucleotide-binding protein (HINT) family enzymes and SMPDL3A might generally contribute to activation of the other bisamidate prodrugs.

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: CS-917 is a bisamidate prodrug of R-125338, which inhibits FBPase in the human liver in a low nano-molar range (IC50: 16 nmol/L) (Erion et al. 2005).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: R-125338 was designed to target the adenosine monophosphate (AMP)-binding site of FBPase using a structure-based drug design (Erion et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Although R-125338 showed good FBPase inhibition, its oral bioavailability was not sufficient.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To improve the oral bioavailability of R-125338, CS-917 was designed as a bisamidate prodrug of R-125338, which gave us sufficient bioavailability and FBPase inhibition in vivo (Dang et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: After oral administration, CS-917 is converted into the active form, R-125338, by a two-step enzyme-catalyzed reaction ( Fig. 1) in rat hepatocytes (Dang et al. 2007) and primary human hepatocytes (Erion et al. 2005).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the first step, CS-917 is hydrolyzed by an esterase and the resultant monoester is spontaneously hydrolyzed to form a monoamidate intermediate (R-134450), mainly in the first-pass metabolism in the small intestine and liver.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Then in the second step, the P-N bond of the intermediate is hydrolyzed by a phosphoramidase to generate the active form, R-125338, mainly in the liver.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Investigation of the conversion rate using rat, monkey, and human liver homogenates demonstrated that the first esterase-catalyzed step was fast and that the second phosphoramidase-catalyzed step was slow and rate-limiting, analogous to other phosphoramidase prodrugs (Saboulard et al. 1999;Beltran et al. 2001).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Clinical studies showed a good maximum plasma concentration and total exposure of R-125338 indicating efficient conversion in humans as expected, although bioavailability in humans cannot be calculated due to the lack of pharmacokinetic data of intravenous administration of R-125338 (Walker et al. 2006).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A large variability in the plasma concentration of CS-917 and R-125338 was also observed.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Since CS-917 esterase activity in human plasma was relatively weak compared to that in the small intestine and liver (data not shown), the plasma concentration of CS-917 would be determined by the degree of CS-917 hydrolysis in the first-pass metabolism and phosphoramidase of the intermediate R-134450 could contribute to R-125338 variation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Phosphoramidate prodrugs have been exploited for the delivery of nucleoside monophosphate antiviral and anticancer agents (Abraham et al. 1996;Saboulard et al. 1999;Beltran et al. 2001;Egron et al. 2003), and molecular characterization of the activation process of nucleotide bisamidate prodrugs has been described recently.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Birkus et al. (2007) identified cathepsin A (CTSA) as the first hydrolysis esterase by biochemical purification for GS-7340 and GS-9131, anti-retroviral nucleotide  Figure 1.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Two-step activation of bisamidate prodrug CS-917 to the active form, R-125338.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: CS-917 is activated into the active form (R-125338) by a two-step enzyme-catalyzed reaction after oral administration.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the first step, CS-917 is hydrolyzed by an esterase and the resultant monoester is spontaneously hydrolyzed to form a monoamidate intermediate (R-134450) in the small intestine and the liver.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the second step, the P-N bond of the R-134450 is hydrolyzed by a phosphoramidase to generate R-125338 in the liver.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The first step is observed to be fast and the second step is observed to be slow and rate-limiting.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: phosphoramidate prodrugs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the study of GS-9191, a prodrug for human papillomavirus treatment, they also found CTSA for the first esterase and contribution of both the unidentified enzyme and acid-driven hydrolysis for the second P-N bond cleavage (Birkus et al. 2011).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Murakami et al. demonstrated carboxylesterase 1 (CES1) and CTSA involvement for the first ester hydrolysis and histidine triad nucleotide-binding protein 1 (HINT1) for the second phosphoramidase hydrolysis for PSI-7851, an anti-hepatitis C virus nucleotide prodrug (Murakami et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: They also reported CES1, CES2, and CTSA for the first hydrolysis and HINT1 for the second hydrolysis for the related drug, GS-6620 (Murakami et al. 2014).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These previous studies showed that different enzymes were involved from compound to compound.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To understand the pharmacodynamics/pharmacokinetics of CS-917, including the variability of the plasma concentration of R-125338, identification of CS-917 esterase and R-134450 phosphoramidase at a molecular level was necessary.
body_text.section: FBPase inhibition

body_text.text: The structure of CS-917 is different from that of those nucleotide bisamidate prodrugs for anti-viral treatment, thus there is a possibility of unexpected enzymes which contribute to the activation process, although these studies provided candidate enzymes.
body_text.section: FBPase inhibition

body_text.text: Here, we describe successful identifications of both CS-917 esterase in the small intestine and liver and R-134450 phosphoramidase in the liver by biochemical purification to identify unexpected enzymes.

body_text.text: All purification procedures were conducted at 4°C and the small intestines from 5 monkeys (monkey #1 to #5) were separately investigated.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: Each cynomolgus monkey small intestine was minced and homogenized in nine volumes of 10 mmol/L 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES), pH 7.0, containing 0.25 mol/ L sucrose and a protease inhibitor cocktail (complete tablet; Roche Applied Science, Indianapolis, IN, USA) using a polytron homogenizer (Kinematica, Luzern, Switzerland).
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The homogenate was filtrated by a few sheets of gauze, the filtrate was sonicated by a Bioruptor (COSMO BIO, Tokyo, Japan), and the suspension was centrifuged at 25,000g for 1 h.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: To the supernatant, ammonium sulfate was added to 20% saturation, which was then stirred for 3 h and centrifuged at 18,000g for 30 min.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: To the collected supernatant, ammonium sulfate was further added to 70% saturation, which was then stirred for 12 h and centrifuged at 18,000g for 30 min.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The collected 20-70% saturated ammonium sulfate precipitate was stored at À80°C until use.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: Ammonium sulfate precipitate equivalent to 12 g of monkey small intestines was dissolved in 80 mL of 20 mmol/L HEPES, pH 7.0, containing 1 mol/L ammonium sulfate, and dialyzed against 2 L of the same buffer.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The dialyzed sample was centrifuged at 15,000g for 10 min, and the supernatant was filtrated and loaded onto a hydrophobic interaction chromatography (HIC) column (HiPrep Butyl 4 FF; GE Healthcare, Pittsburgh, PA, USA).
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradient from 1 to 0 mol/L ammonium sulfate in 20 mmol/L HEPES, pH 7.0.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: Each fraction was tested for CS-917 esterase activity.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The CS-917 esterase activity formed two peaks (the first active peak and the second active peak) in the case of the small intestine from monkey #1.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: For the first active peak purification, the active fractions (20 mL) were dialyzed against 2 L of HC buffer (20 mmol/L HEPES, pH 7.0, containing 0.1% [w/v] 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl) dimethylammonio] propanesulfonic acid [CHAPS]).
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The dialyzed sample was loaded onto a dye-affinity column (HiTrap Blue HP 1 mL; GE Healthcare) and the bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradient of 0-2 mol/L NaCl in HC buffer.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The active fractions (2 mL) were dialyzed against 1 L of HC buffer.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The dialyzed sample was loaded onto an anion exchange column (Mini Q PC 3.2/3; GE Healthcare), and the bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradient of 0-350 mmol/L NaCl in HC buffer.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: A portion of the active fraction (50 lL) from the Mini Q column was loaded onto a gel filtration column (Superdex 200 PC 3.2/30; GE Healthcare) equilibrated with 20 mmol/L HEPES, pH 7.0, containing 150 mmol/L NaCl and 0.1% CHAPS.
body_text.section: Purification of small intestine CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: For the second active peak purification, the active fractions (20 mL) were dialyzed against 10 mmol/L sodium phosphate, pH 6.8, containing 0.1% CHAPS.

body_text.text: A monkey liver homogenate was prepared as described above.

body_text.text: Ammonium sulfate precipitate equivalent to 30 g of monkey liver was dissolved in 50 mL of CEX buffer (20 mmol/L CH 3 COONa, pH 4.0, containing 0.1% CHAPS, 5 mmol/L MgCl 2 and 1 mmol/L dithiothreitol [DTT]) and dialyzed against 2 L of CEX buffer.

body_text.section: Purification of liver CS-917 esterase

body_text.text: The bound proteins were eluted with a linear gradient of 0-300 mmol/L NaCl in CEX buffer.

body_text.text: Human genes of CES1, CES2, elastase 2A (ELA2A), ELA2B, ELA3A, ELA3B, HINT3, aprataxin (APTX) and sphingomyelin phosphodiesterase, and acid-like (SMPDL3A) were amplified by a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) from human brains, livers, pancreas, skeletal muscle, prostates, or their mixed cDNA library.

body_text.text: HINT1 and HINT3 were amplified from a commercially available cDNA clone (Ultimate clone; Invitrogen, Tokyo, Japan).

body_text.text: In the case of proteins with secretion signal sequences (CES1, CES2, ELA2A, ELA2B, ELA3A, ELA3B, and SMPDL3A), an entry clone was recombined with a pFLAG-CMV-5.1GW destination vector, in which the gene was fused with a C-terminal FLAG-tag by a Gateway LR reaction.

body_text.text: In other cases (HINT1, HINT2, HINT3, APTX), each entry clone was recombined with pFLAG-CMV-2GW in which the gene was fused with an N-terminal FLAG-tag.

body_text.section: CS-917 esterase assay

body_text.text: To stop the reaction, the sample was mixed with 100 lL of methanol, and 10 lL of the filtrate (0.45 lm; Millipore) was subjected to a reversed-phase chromatography column (ZORBAX SB C18, 2.1 mm ID 9 0 mm length, 1.8 lm; Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA), which was conditioned at 40°C and pre-equilibrated with 20 mmol/L triethylamine acetate (TEAA), pH 7.0, containing 5% acetonitrile.
body_text.section: CS-917 esterase assay

body_text.text: The compounds were eluted with a linear gradient of 5-95% acetonitrile in 20 mmol/L TEAA, pH 7.0, over 2.5 min at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min.
body_text.section: CS-917 esterase assay

body_text.text: Absorbance at 303 nm was monitored, and CS-917 esterase activity was determined by measuring the peak area of the produced R-134450 using a known amount of a synthesized R-134450 as the standards.
body_text.section: CS-917 esterase assay

body_text.text: One unit of CS-917 esterase activity was defined as the activity required for 1 lg/mL production of R-134450 under these experimental conditions.
body_text.section: CS-917 esterase assay

body_text.text: To the 35 lL of the sample was added 5 lL of 1 mol/L HEPES, pH 7.0, 5 lL of 2 mg/mL BSA and 5 lL of 10 mmol/L R-134450 dissolved in 5% dimethyl sulfoxide, and this was incubated at 37°C for 1 h.
body_text.section: R-134450 phosphoramidase assay

body_text.text: After the reaction, the sample was mixed with 100 lL of methanol to inactivate the enzyme and 10 lL of the filtrate (0.45 lm) was subjected to a reversed-phase chromatography column (XTerra MS C18 5 lm, 4.6 mm ID 9 150 mm length; Waters, Milford, MA, USA) with a guard column of the same material (3.9 mm ID 9 20 mm length, Waters), then analyzed with isocratic elution in 10 mmol/L TEAA, pH 7.0, containing 16% acetonitrile.
body_text.section: R-134450 phosphoramidase assay

body_text.text: Absorbance at 260 nm was monitored, and R-134450 phosphoramidase activity was determined by measuring the peak area of produced R-125338, using a known amount of synthesized R-125338 as the standard.
body_text.section: R-134450 phosphoramidase assay

body_text.text: One unit/mL R-134450 phosphoramidase activity was defined as the concentration required for 1 lmol/L production of R-125338 under these experimental conditions.
body_text.section: R-134450 phosphoramidase assay

body_text.text: The total protein concentration was determined by a modified Bradford assay (Coomassie Plus Protein Assay; Pierce, Tokyo, Japan), using BSA as a standard protein.
body_text.section: Protein assay

body_text.text: All experiments were independently conducted more than once to confirm reproducibility except Figure 4, where we show all of the data from individual animals.

body_text.section: Compliance with design and statistical analysis requirements

body_text.text: To identify the enzyme responsible for CS-917 esterase activity in the small intestine, we used cynomolgus monkeys as a purification source because of the abundant sample availability and their similarity to humans.

body_text.text: The monkey small intestine was homogenized and separated to nuclear, mitochondrial, microsomal, and cytosolic fractions by centrifugation and the activity was found to be mostly localized in the cytosolic and soluble fraction (Fig. S1).

body_text.text: The observed molecular weight of the activity was 60-70 kDa determined by gel filtration chromatography, and interestingly, the activity from one out of the five monkeys (monkey #1) was bound to an HIC column and formed two almost equivalent peaks ( Fig. 2A).

body_text.text: On the other hand, the second peak was not bound to either the blue dye or the heparin affinity columns, but was bound to a hydroxylapatite column.
body_text.section: Purification and identification of ELA3B and CTSA as CS-917 esterases in monkey small intestines

body_text.text: Based on their characters, we purified CS-917 esterase activity from the small intestine from monkey #1.

body_text.text: As a result of successive five-step purification, the first and the second active peaks were purified more than 4000-fold (Table 1) and 8000fold (Table 2), respectively.
body_text.section: Purification and identification of ELA3B and CTSA as CS-917 esterases in monkey small intestines

body_text.text: In the fourth (Fig. S2A and B) and final ( Fig. 2B and C) purification step of the first active peak, we found bands of 30, 17, and 15 kDa on SDS-PAGE gels which correlated well with the CS-917 esterase activity.
body_text.section: Purification and identification of ELA3B and CTSA as CS-917 esterases in monkey small intestines

body_text.text: Therefore, we analyzed the proteins in these three bands by mass spectrometry and identified monkey elastase 3B (NCBI gene identifier: 62510667, human homologous gene symbol: ELA3B) from all three bands.

body_text.text: Similarly, in the fourth (Fig. S2C and D) and final ( Fig. 2D and E) purification step of the second active peak, we found bands of 26 and 17 kDa on SDS-PAGE gels which correlated well with the enzyme activity, and we identified the protein in these bands as monkey cathepsin A (NCBI gene identifier: 109091751, human homologous gene symbol: CTSA) by mass spectrometry.

body_text.text: To confirm that CTSA and ELA3B have CS-917 esterase activity and to determine whether other possible candidate genes have CS-917 esterase activity, we compared the specific activity of the candidate genes for CS-917 esterase.

body_text.text: We cloned human homologous genes because our final goal is to identify CS-917 esterase in humans.
body_text.section: Confirmation of CS-917 esterase activity of candidate genes in the small intestine

body_text.text: Considering the differences between species, we regarded other human pancreatic elastases (ELA2A, ELA2B and ELA3A) as candidates for CS-917 esterase in addition to ELA3B.

body_text.section: Confirmation of CS-917 esterase activity of candidate genes in the small intestine

body_text.text: As shown in Figure 3, CTSA demonstrated the highest specific activity as CS-917 esterase while ELA2 and ELA3B exhibited moderate specific activity, and ELA3A showed weak specific activity.

body_text.text: ELA2A and ELA2B did not hydrolase CS-917.
body_text.section: Confirmation of CS-917 esterase activity of candidate genes in the small intestine

body_text.text: In parallel, we tested ELA2A and ELA2B's elastase activity using synthetic peptide substrates.

body_text.text: The results revealed ELA2A had elastase activity but ELA2B did not (Fig. S3), indicating that our ELA2A was certainly active but did not have CS-917 esterase activity.

body_text.text: With regard to ELA2B, a recent report showed ELA2B was devoid of proteolytic activity (Szepessy and Sahin Toth 2006).

body_text.text: Phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) is an inhibitor for a broad range of serine proteases.

body_text.text: Since both ELA3B and CTSA are serine proteases, we tested its inhibitory effect on the elastases and CTSA.

body_text.text: Interestingly, we found that all 4 homogenates prepared from monkeys (monkey #2 to #5) other than monkey #1 formed a single active peak after HIC column separation and that the activity was relatively insensitive to 1 mmol/L PMSF (Fig. 4).
body_text.section: Confirmation of CS-917 esterase activity of candidate genes in the small intestine

body_text.text: These observations strongly suggested that CTSA was the major CS-917 esterase in monkey small intestine homogenates and that monkey #1 was exceptional for unknown reasons, probably insufficient washing of the inside of the small intestine.

body_text.text: CES is well known as an activating enzyme for many prodrugs, including bisamidate prodrugs and is supposed to be a good candidate for an additional CS-917 esterase in the liver (Imai 2006;Liederer and Borchardt 2006;Satoh and Hosokawa 2006;Murakami et al. 2010).

body_text.text: We identified the protein of these 50 kDa bands by mass spectrometry as sphingomyelin phosphodiesterase, acid-like 3A (Human homologous gene symbol: SMPDL3A).
body_text.section: Purification and identification of SMPDL3A as the intermediate (R-134450) phosphoramidase in monkey liver

body_text.text: As far as we know, only two genes were reported as phosphoramidases in the literature (Bieganowski et al. 2002;Seidle et al. 2005).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: These two genes, HINT1 and APTX, belong to the same HINT enzyme family, and this HINT enzyme family consists of four genes (HINT1, HINT2, HINT3, and APTX) in humans.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: HINT1 could hydrolyze the phosphoramide bond of AMP-lysine (Bieganowski et al. 2002) and moreover the bisamidate nucleotide prodrug PSI-7851 (Murakami et al. 2010).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In addition, APTX was also found to have the same AMP-lysine phosphoramidase activity (Seidle et al. 2005).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Therefore, we included these four HINT family genes as candidate genes for R-134450 in addition to SMPDL3A, although none of ELA2, should play an important role in determining the CS-917 amount in the liver, and CTSA and CES1 would be an important factor for R-125338 concentration in the liver.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Elastases belong to the serine protease family.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In humans, six elastase genes (elastase 1 (ELA1), ELA2, ELA2A, ELA2B, ELA3A, and ELA3B) are known.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: ELA1 is expressed in skin keratinocytes (Kawashima et al. 1992;Talas et al. 2000).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: ELA2, also known as neutrophil elastase or leukocyte elastase, is expressed in bone marrow myelocytic precursor cells, mostly promyelocytes (Fouret et al. 1989;Lee and Downey 2001).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: ELA2A, ELA2B, ELA3A, and ELA3B are known as pancreatic elastases, which are expressed and stored as an inactive zymogen in the pancreas, secreted into the intestine, activated by trypsin and participate in food digestion (Hartley and Shotton 1971;Shen et al. 1987;Tani et al. 1988;Fouret et al. 1989).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Although the elastase was defined as a protease which degrades elastin, ELA3A and ELA3B are known to have a slight elastolytic activity but do have protease activity with preferential cleavage after alanine (Bode et al. 1989).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: The partial structure around the hydrolyzed ester of CS-917 was alanine ethyl ester, which supported ELA3B as the CS-917 esterase.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: It was reported that mature ELA3A/ELA3B had a molecular weight of 30 kDa and highly concentrated ELA3A/ELA3B showed rapid autolysis (Mallory and Travis 1975), which suggested that the 17 and 15 kDa identified as ELA3B by mass spectrometry would be its autodigested products (Fig. 2B).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: All of the data were consistent with ELA3B as one of the CS-917 esterases in the small intestine.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: CTSA, also known as a lysosomal protective protein or lysosomal carboxypeptidase A, is a serine protease expressed ubiquitously (Hiraiwa 1999).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: This enzyme has three distinctive enzymatic activities: (1) peptidase activity optimal at pH 5.0 and (2) esterase and (3) deamidase activity optimal at pH 7.0 (Jackman et al. 1990).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Besides its catalytic activities, it plays an important role in stabilizing lysosomal b-galactosidase and neuraminidase by its association.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Interestingly, this protective function is independent of its catalytic activities (Galjart et al. 1991).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: CTSA is synthesized as a precursor of 54 kDa which is proteolytically processed into a mature two-chain form of 32 and 20 kDa polypeptides linked by disulfide bridges.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: This agrees well with the observations that the 26 and 17 kDa bands under a reducing condition (Fig. 2D) correlated well with CS-917 esterase activity on SDS-PAGE gels and were all identified as CTSA by mass spectrometry.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: SMPDL3A, also referred to as acid sphingomyelinaselike phosphodiesterase 3a (ASML3a), is a protein whose biological or enzymatic function is mostly unknown.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: One study using a yeast 2-hybrid system reported that SMPDL3A interacts with the tumor suppressor gene deleted in the bladder cancer chromosome region 1 (DBCCR1) (Wright et al. 2002), and another study demonstrated SMPDL3A expression is regulated by liver X receptors (LXRs) (Noto et al. 2012).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: We found that the protein has one predicted phosphohydrolase domain (COG1409, NCBI), where the phosphoramidase reaction is similar to the phosphohydrolase reaction.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: mRNA expression of human SMPDL3A was high in the skin, small intestine, colon, rectum, liver, kidney, and prostate but low in other tissues, including blood vessels, which was consistent with the observation of the R-134450 phosphoramidase activity profile (data not shown).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: All experimental data supported that SMPDL3A was the enzyme responsible for R-134450 phosphoramidase activity.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Hint3 APTX Figure 7.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Specific R-134450 phosphoramidase activity of candidate genes.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Candidate genes (SMPDL3A, HINT1, HINT2, HINT3, and APTX) and the negative control (EGFP) were expressed in the human cell line, the recombinant proteins were purified using fused FLAG-tag, and the R-134450 phosphoramidase activity was tested.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: The purified proteins were quantified by Western blotting, and the specific activity was calculated.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Four to seven independent experiments were conducted (4 for HINT1, HINT2, HINT3, and APTX, and 7 for EGFP and SMPDL3A).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: The results are expressed as the means AE SD (three technical replicates from a single experiment).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: EGFP, enhanced green fluorescent protein.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: We have identified SMPDL3A as an R-134450 phosphoramidase, which is thought to be a rate-limiting enzyme for CS-917 activation (Erion et al. 2005;Dang et al. 2007).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: We deduced that SMPDL3A, not HINT1, is the major R-134450 phosphoramidase in vivo because of the reasons below: (1) The enzyme activity formed a single peak in all purification steps, which suggested the enzyme in the monkey liver was unique; (2) Only SMPDL3A showed relatively strong specific activity compared to HINT family proteins; (3) We tested the R-134450 phosphoramidase activity of two isoforms of SMPDL3B, the most homologous protein to SMPDL3A, but they did not show any R-134450 phosphoramidase activity (data not shown) because homologous drug metabolism enzymes often have similar enzyme activity.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: To determine whether SMPDL3A is the major enzyme responsible for R-134450 phosphoramidase activity, further studies are needed.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: For example, a neutralizing antibody against SMPDL3A can be used for such experiments.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Moreover, investigation of the relationship between SMPDL3A and pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic analysis of CS-917 will reveal the importance of SMPDL3A in CS-917 activation.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In previous literatures, contribution of CTSA for the first ester hydrolysis of nucleotide bisamidate prodrugs was reported for GS-7340 and GS-9131 (Birkus et al. 2007), PSI-7851 (Murakami et al. 2010), GS-9191 (Birkus et al. 2011) and GS-6620 (Murakami et al. 2014), whereas CES1 was partially involved, such as with PSI-7851 (Murakami et al. 2010) and GS-6620 (Murakami et al. 2014).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Neutrophil elastase (ELA2) was also described to have the esterase activity for PSI-7851 (Murakami et al. 2010) and we identified ELA3B as CS-917 esterase.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Therefore, the first step reaction of CS-917 was found to be similar to those nucleotide prodrugs.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: On the other hand, HINT1 (Murakami et al. 2010(Murakami et al. , 2014 or an unidentified enzyme (Saboulard et al. 1999;Birkus et al. 2011) or acid-driven hydrolysis (Birkus et al. 2011) was described for the second hydrolysis of the P-N bond for prodrugs, which was different from SMPDL3A in CS-917.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Thus, SMPDL3A would be the first identified phosphoramidase other than the HINT family enzymes.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Saboulard et al. (1999) reported that anti-HIV prodrug phosphoramidase from rat liver was enriched in a cytosolic fraction and that its observed molecular weight was 50-100 kDa.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: These data agree well with the characteristics of SMPDL3A, but not with HINT1 or APTX.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Thus, SMPDL3A might be the unreported phosphoramidase for the anti-HIV prodrug.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Identification of an enzyme based on biochemical purification is sometimes regarded as a classic and conservative approach.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In this study, we purified ELA3B and CTSA from monkey small intestine (Fig. 2, Tables 1, 2) and SMPDL3A from monkey liver ( Fig. 6 and Table 3).
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Technical limitations of this study were to use monkey tissue as starting materials for purification, and the potential to bias activities observed toward a more stable enzyme by a biochemical purification approach.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: However, many enzymes were discovered through this approach, especially the discovery of unforeseen enzymes, and once we identify the candidates, we could validate the candidates by the following experiments using human samples.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Human recombinant protein experiments (Figs. 3, 7) in this study are the initial step, and correlation analysis between inter-individual enzyme activity and candidate proteins, a selective inhibitor experiment and gene knockout animal experiment would follow for the purpose.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In the purification scheme, recovery of enzyme activities at the early purification steps showed more than 100%.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: This is not an uncommon observation as we reported previously (Yonesu et al. 2011) and as written by others (Ryan 1996), indicating a presence of inhibitors of the enzyme reaction in crude samples.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: With regard to identification strategy, CES1 and CTSA can be expected as a CS-917 esterase, ELA3B could be speculated based on the activity of ELA2 for PSI-7851 (Murakami et al. 2010), however identification of SMPDL3A as an R-134450 phosphoramidase was completely unexpected because SMPDL3A was very far from the HINT family proteins which have only been reported as having phosphoramidase activity.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Recent advancement of proteomics technology has made the requirements to identify candidate proteins much lower than before.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: We did not have to purify candidate proteins to homogeneity.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Instead, in this study, we identified candidate proteins from faint bands of a nanogram level which correlated with enzyme activity (Figs. 2, 6) or even without SDS-PAGE ( Fig. 5) by using a quantitation method by mass spectrometry.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Recently, we reported the carboxymethylene butenolidase homolog (CMBL) as a hydrolase of a new antihypertensive drug, olmesartan medoxomil, by the same strategy (Ishizuka et al. 2010), where the identified protein was also completely unexpected.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: The classical biochemical approach with cuttingedge proteomics technology could contribute to identify enzymes beyond our limited imagination.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In conclusion, we identified the enzymes involved in both two-step activation processes of the novel phosphoramidate prodrug, CS-917, at the molecular level.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: All of the observations presented here were obtained through in vitro experiments, thus the next challenge would be to determine the contribution of enzymes identified in this study in vivo, as other enzymes or even nonenzymatic lysosomal hydrolysis could be involved.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Nevertheless, this study would be an important, initial, and necessary step for a better understanding of the activation mechanism, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacokinetics of this new drug candidate and possibly other phosphoramidate pro- drugs.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: Novel identification of new phosphoramidase, which could be responsible for the activation process of other bisamidate drugs, would contribute to research and development of this class of prodrugs in the future.
body_text.section: Confirmation and comparison of candidate genes for R-134450 phosphoramidase

body_text.text: In addition, this study would be another good example showing that our biochemical approach with proteomics technology is an efficient strategy to identify unexpected metabolic enzymes, which are supposed to be necessary in the personalized medicine era.

We cloned the human genes of SMPDL3A, HINT1, HINT2, HINT3, and APTX, produced recombinant proteins in human cells, purified them using FLAG-tag fused with the protein, and tested their R-134450 phosphoramidase activity.
As shown in Figure 7, SMPDL3A showed remarkable R-134450 phosphoramidase activity while HINT1, HINT2, and APTX had much weaker specific activity than SMPDL3A.
In this study, we molecularly identified the enzymes that can catalyze the activation process of a bisamidate prodrug, CS-917.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: As activating enzymes in the first step, we purified and identified CTSA and ELA3B from the monkey small intestine.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: We also found ELA2 had relatively weak CS-917 esterase activity.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Based on the fact that homogenates from only one specific monkey showed high CS-917 esterase activity derived from ELA3B (Figs. 2,4) and the immunodepletion experiment ( Fig. S5), CTSA was probably the major responsible enzyme for CS-917 esterase activity in the small intestine.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In addition, we have revealed that CES1 could contribute as CS-917 esterase as well as CTSA in the liver.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Orally administrated CS-917 would be partially hydrolyzed by pancreatic elastases, mainly ELA3B, in the lumen of the small intestine and would be further hydrolyzed by CTSA in the small intestine.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: CS-917 that escaped from those enzymes in the small intestine would be hydrolyzed by CTSA and CES1 in the liver, which is the target organ of CS-917.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: CS-917 hydrolyzed before reaching the liver would hardly contribute to the drug action of CS-917, because R-134450 is hydrophilic and has a low transition between organs due to its low membrane permeability.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: CS-917 esterase activity in human plasma was very weak compared to that in the small intestine or liver (data not shown), which indicated ELA2 was a minor factor in CS-917 metabolism.
body_text.section: Discussion
